disclaimer.text: This calculator provides accurate date calculations based on the Gregorian calendar. Business day calculations exclude weekends (Saturday and Sunday) but do not account for holidays.
disclaimer.note: Business days are calculated as Monday through Friday. For precise business day calculations including regional holidays, consult a holiday-aware calendar system.

seo.whatIsContent: A date calculator is a versatile tool that performs date arithmetic and comparisons. It can calculate the exact difference between two dates (in years, months, weeks, and days) or add/subtract time periods from a specific date to find a future or past date.
seo.howItWorksContent: The calculator uses the Gregorian calendar system with algorithms that account for varying month lengths (28-31 days) and leap years. When finding the difference between dates, it calculates the total elapsed time and breaks it down into years, months, and days.
seo.feature1: Find the exact time span between two dates in years, months, days, and weeks
seo.feature2: Add or subtract any combination of years, months, weeks, and days
seo.feature3: Automatically handles leap years and varying month lengths
seo.feature4: View results in multiple formats (breakdown or totals)
seo.useCase1: Calculate project timelines, milestone dates, and deadline tracking
seo.useCase2: Determine contract expiration dates and legal notice periods

seo.useCase4: Determine loan maturity dates and investment holding periods
seo.tip1: Adding months to January 31 adjusts to last day of target month (Feb 28/29)
seo.tip2: Leap years: divisible by 4, except centuries unless divisible by 400
seo.tip3: Gregorian calendar dates work best from October 1582 onwards
seo.tip4: Use include end date option for inclusive counting
seo.faq1Question: How accurate is this date calculator?
seo.faq1Answer: This calculator is completely accurate for all dates in the Gregorian calendar (1582 onwards). It correctly handles leap years, varying month lengths, and all calendar edge cases.
seo.faq2Question: What happens when adding months to end-of-month dates?
seo.faq2Answer: When you add months to a date like January 31, the calculator adjusts to the last valid day of the target month. January 31 + 1 month = February 28 (or 29 in a leap year).
seo.faq3Question: How do leap years affect date calculations?
seo.faq3Answer: Leap years occur every 4 years (except centuries unless divisible by 400). February has 29 days in leap years. The calculator automatically accounts for this.
seo.faq4Question: Can I calculate dates far in the past or future?
seo.faq4Answer: Yes, the calculator works for any date from October 1582 (Gregorian calendar adoption) through the foreseeable future.
seo.faq5Question: What's the difference between total days and the breakdown?
seo.faq5Answer: Total days is the complete count (e.g., 400 days). The breakdown expresses the same period as years, months, and days (e.g., 1 year, 1 month, 5 days).
seo.faq6Question: How do I calculate someone's exact age?
seo.faq6Answer: Use 'Find Date Difference' mode with their birth date as start and today as end. For more detail including zodiac signs, use our Age Calculator.
seo.faq7Question: Does this include or exclude the end date?
seo.faq7Answer: You can choose with the 'Include end date in count' option. Enable it to count both start and end dates, disable for exclusive counting.
seo.faq8Question: How do I subtract time from a date?
seo.faq8Answer: Select 'Add/Subtract Time' mode, choose 'Subtract', enter the years, months, weeks, or days to subtract, and the calculator shows the resulting date.
seo.howToStep1: Select 'Find Date Difference' or 'Add/Subtract Time' mode
seo.howToStep2: Enter start and end dates, or base date and time values
seo.howToStep3: Choose whether to include end date in count
seo.howToStep4: View the difference in years, months, days and total days
seo.howToStep5: Use the resulting date or difference for your planning
